snippet.textDisplay: For sure - no need to upgrade from a SATA based SSD to an NVME SSD just for a performance boost - space reasons, sure (esp. if one is running low on it which can slow down SSD's).  Def worth while to avoid DRAMless SSD's entirely, and very much worth upgrading from a DRAMless SSD to a DRAMed one
snippet.textOriginal: For sure - no need to upgrade from a SATA based SSD to an NVME SSD just for a performance boost - space reasons, sure (esp. if one is running low on it which can slow down SSD's).  Def worth while to avoid DRAMless SSD's entirely, and very much worth upgrading from a DRAMless SSD to a DRAMed one

snippet.textDisplay: Well, in my experience, the only difference I could feel between SSDs was, using a cheap Sata SSD (was from SiliconPower), and using a good SSD like the 860 Evo from samsung, I was %100 able to tell the difference between them both. Especially in cases where there's already load on the SSD, and then if I try to load up something else, the cheaper SSD would cause the system to freeze, and the response times would go up the roof. Whereas the Samsung drive would never lag that much even if you're copying a file or doing whatever. I found response times much more effective than read and write speeds. (I'm not actually sure which metric directly affects the responsiveness of a drive, but yee)
snippet.textOriginal: Well, in my experience, the only difference I could feel between SSDs was, using a cheap Sata SSD (was from SiliconPower), and using a good SSD like the 860 Evo from samsung, I was %100 able to tell the difference between them both. Especially in cases where there's already load on the SSD, and then if I try to load up something else, the cheaper SSD would cause the system to freeze, and the response times would go up the roof. Whereas the Samsung drive would never lag that much even if you're copying a file or doing whatever. I found response times much more effective than read and write speeds. (I'm not actually sure which metric directly affects the responsiveness of a drive, but yee)

snippet.textDisplay:
I use old, not that fast HDDs for storage of files I rarely use, and for editing pictures or pulling videos from them it doesn't make that big of a difference. I wouldn't use them for gaming, but even for editing videos, if you keep the files you currently work with on other drive, pulling resources from them is not a significant problem.

So don't even waste your money on SSDs to hoard data. HDDs are good enough. If you consider buying a four gigabyte SSD, unless you are really into gaming or do editing as your job, just save your money.
snippet.textOriginal:
I use old, not that fast HDDs for storage of files I rarely use, and for editing pictures or pulling videos from them it doesn't make that big of a difference. I wouldn't use them for gaming, but even for editing videos, if you keep the files you currently work with on other drive, pulling resources from them is not a significant problem.

So don't even waste your money on SSDs to hoard data. HDDs are good enough. If you consider buying a four gigabyte SSD, unless you are really into gaming or do editing as your job, just save your money.

snippet.textDisplay:
Theres something wrong going on in this video.


Just look at 2:19 on the machine on the front you can see it has an Nvme gen 3 drive, wich doesn't corelate to the positions revealed at the end, since that machine has to have a computer at it's left when looking at it from the front, wich means it has to be in the position marked in the results as Nvme gen 4 or Sata.
And the ram on the machine on the background is placed together, wich signals that it's a M-Atx board since there is no more space for more ram, wich some models cut performance in favor of a smaller form factor.
And the one with ram placed together is the one labeled in the results as Nvme gen 3 or Nvme gen 4.
I guess they could have suffled them after taking that shot, but that seems unlikely since it is a lot of work to move and rewire them again.
snippet.textOriginal:
Theres something wrong going on in this video.


Just look at 2:19 on the machine on the front you can see it has an Nvme gen 3 drive, wich doesn't corelate to the positions revealed at the end, since that machine has to have a computer at it's left when looking at it from the front, wich means it has to be in the position marked in the results as Nvme gen 4 or Sata.
And the ram on the machine on the background is placed together, wich signals that it's a M-Atx board since there is no more space for more ram, wich some models cut performance in favor of a smaller form factor.
And the one with ram placed together is the one labeled in the results as Nvme gen 3 or Nvme gen 4.
I guess they could have suffled them after taking that shot, but that seems unlikely since it is a lot of work to move and rewire them again.

snippet.textDisplay: Smartass mode activated! This is called the primacy-recency-effect or serial-position effect in user studies. Participants are, in general, biased towards the first or the last element of a rating test. This is common behavior for both QoE and QoS studies using both trained as well as untrained participants. To ensure comparability and generalizability, you would have to repeat the test several times and see if a transient phase within the results of single participants can be detected, which would need to be trimmed.
snippet.textOriginal: Smartass mode activated! This is called the primacy-recency-effect or serial-position effect in user studies. Participants are, in general, biased towards the first or the last element of a rating test. This is common behavior for both QoE and QoS studies using both trained as well as untrained participants. To ensure comparability and generalizability, you would have to repeat the test several times and see if a transient phase within the results of single participants can be detected, which would need to be trimmed.

snippet.textDisplay: It is not just for gaming that there is little difference between SATA and NVMe. I recently evaluated different options for Elasticsearch storage, expecting NVMe to be the clear winner. However a SATA SSD could match it, and 2 SATA drives in RAID0 clearly beat it. Also tested was 4 HDDs in RAID0, but the result was well behind the SSDs. https://youtu.be/nKUpfJCBiS4
snippet.textOriginal: It is not just for gaming that there is little difference between SATA and NVMe. I recently evaluated different options for Elasticsearch storage, expecting NVMe to be the clear winner. However a SATA SSD could match it, and 2 SATA drives in RAID0 clearly beat it. Also tested was 4 HDDs in RAID0, but the result was well behind the SSDs.  https://youtu.be/nKUpfJCBiS4

snippet.textDisplay:
*)When the cpu base clock are between 3ghz and can overclocked to 6ghz(maybe), you should pair it with 3200-4000mhz memory.

*)When your cpu memory cache capacity is 256mb/s, you should pair it with 256-1.000mb/s ssd. Bottleneck when you using <256mb/s ssd😂🤣

*) When you using 3gb/s ssd, you should look at the cable that you using for? How much data can delivered by that cable.
Bottleneck or slow transfer when you pair usb 2.0/3.0 and thunderbolt 3.0 for transfering data from the 3-4gb/s ssd that should you paired with the thunderbolt 3.1/3.2 maybe🤣
snippet.textOriginal:
*)When the cpu base clock are between 3ghz and can overclocked to 6ghz(maybe), you should pair it with 3200-4000mhz memory.

*)When your cpu memory cache capacity is 256mb/s, you should pair it with 256-1.000mb/s ssd. Bottleneck when you using <256mb/s ssd😂🤣

*) When you using 3gb/s ssd, you should look at the cable that you using for? How much data can delivered by that cable.
Bottleneck or slow transfer when you pair usb 2.0/3.0 and thunderbolt 3.0 for transfering data from the 3-4gb/s ssd that should you paired with the thunderbolt 3.1/3.2 maybe🤣

snippet.textDisplay:
The stat that actually does give you a noticeable improvement is IOPS. Primarily in boot times, but if you are a developer, then also compiling code, installing dependencies and working with virtual machines for development will give you a very noticeable improvement in NVMe drives vs SATA. Try npm install and webpack compiling on nvme compared to SATA SSD... You won't need a timer to tell the difference.


So if you've got the money get an NVMe drive for work and OS (512Gb will be ore than enough unless you are compiling Chrome and QT or something...), and a SATA SSD for games and other media.
snippet.textOriginal:
The stat that actually does give you a noticeable improvement is IOPS. Primarily in boot times, but if you are a developer, then also compiling code, installing dependencies and working with virtual machines for development will give you a very noticeable improvement in NVMe drives vs SATA. Try npm install and webpack compiling on nvme compared to SATA SSD... You won't need a timer to tell the difference.


So if you've got the money get an NVMe drive for work and OS (512Gb will be ore than enough unless you are compiling Chrome and QT or something...), and a SATA SSD for games and other media.

snippet.textDisplay:
Software always has been behind hardware. Run this test in 3 years and it will be different again. The real thing is that the faster the drive is over the older technology the better the overall system response is. IE like putting an SSD in an older laptop that had a 4800rpm hard drive will make the laptop responsiveness massively improved.
As the old saying goes Horses for courses.
snippet.textOriginal:
Software always has been behind hardware. Run this test in 3 years and it will be different again.  The real thing is that the faster the drive is over the older technology the better the overall system response is.  IE like putting an SSD in an older laptop that had a 4800rpm hard drive will make the laptop responsiveness massively improved.
As the old saying goes Horses for courses.

snippet.textDisplay: So one thing on outright load times is that I’ve been playing some games like Star Wars battlefront II a bunch recently. Very specifically every match there’s a bunch of points where if you get the heroes it’s dependent on how quickly you load in. I have a SATA SSD and sometimes can, while my friend has just a HDD and never does. So while I get why Linus wants to look at the “feel”, sometimes the actual numbers and the drag race are important for video games

snippet.textDisplay:
We have 9 computers at work ranging from cheap sata SSD's on low powered systems to high quality sata SSD's on decent systems to NVMe drives on high end systems.

At this point I would say I cannot easily tell the difference between cheap sata ssd and good sata sad, and not sure about NVMe. At this point I think it has more do with overall hardware, not just SSD type.

Of course going from hdd to ssd was an amazing upgrade. But once you have a high quality ssd, regardless of interface type, you are good to go. We use many of these computers for graphic design (InDesign, Illustrator, Photoshop) and as long as we are not maxing out the CPU or running out of ram, they all preform comparably. It's only in massive, complicated files do we see a difference between the systems, and with Adobe software it often comes down to how fast I gobbles through ram.
snippet.textOriginal:
We have 9 computers at work ranging from cheap sata SSD's on low powered systems to high quality sata SSD's on decent systems to NVMe drives on high end systems.

At this point I would say I cannot easily tell the difference between cheap sata ssd and good sata sad, and not sure about NVMe.  At this point I think it has more do with overall hardware, not just SSD type.

Of course going from hdd to ssd was an amazing upgrade.  But once you have a high quality ssd, regardless of interface type, you are good to go.  We use many of these computers for graphic design (InDesign, Illustrator, Photoshop) and as long as we are not maxing out the CPU or running out of ram, they all preform comparably.  It's only in massive, complicated files do we see a difference between the systems, and with Adobe software it often comes down to how fast I gobbles through ram.

snippet.textDisplay: You can't test if differences are noticeable when you haven't even established that your test setup creates the differences that you are trying to test. Need to start with quantitative tests to confirm your test setup and then qualitatively test if the differences are actually noticeable. I would be looking at games with large dense environments and 4k textures, Battlefield V and Asgard's Wrath come to mind.
snippet.textOriginal: You can't test if differences are noticeable when you haven't even established that your test setup creates the differences that you are trying to test. Need to start with quantitative tests to confirm your test setup and then qualitatively test if the differences are actually noticeable. I would be looking at games with large dense environments and 4k textures, Battlefield V and Asgard's Wrath come to mind.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey, Linus, does not it also say that products which you were using for tests are not designed to use SSD advantages when they are present?

As far as I know there's only one game project with mandatory hardware requirement of SSD. Most of software is designed to be capable of running on conventional HDDs (which I believe still keeps occupied most of home systems for "study and play" worldwide). So the only difference you could've see was based on unintended side effects of their data transfer bandwidth - software simply can't scale it's performance around these values/capabilities (in comparison with traditional performance affecting hardware).
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey, Linus, does not it also say that products which you were using for tests are not designed to use SSD advantages when they are present? 

As far as I know there's only one game project with mandatory hardware requirement of SSD. Most of software is designed to be capable of running on conventional HDDs (which I believe still keeps occupied most of home systems for "study and play" worldwide). So the only difference you could've see was based on unintended side effects of their data transfer bandwidth - software simply can't scale it's performance around these values/capabilities (in comparison with traditional performance affecting hardware).

snippet.textDisplay:
Linus, if you had filmed the performance of these PCs, you might have come to the same conclusion about the SATA having been performing the fastest.
And what about games like Minecraft, where level storing and loading is far more important?

Just because an architecture is "optimal", doesn't mean we're exempt from quirks and lag from everyday use, random Windows slowdowns (of which Win10 has a lot of), and basically other factors of pure chance.

To sit there and just test these guys, who are subject to all sorts of placebo, stress, numerical bias and Cthulhu belief, is not enough to tell what's what.
If you were to measure a significant difference, that means there is a significant difference.
snippet.textOriginal:
Linus, if you had filmed the performance of these PCs, you might have come to the same conclusion about the SATA having been performing the fastest.
And what about games like Minecraft, where level storing and loading is far more important?

Just because an architecture is "optimal", doesn't mean we're exempt from quirks and lag from everyday use, random Windows slowdowns (of which Win10 has a lot of), and basically other factors of pure chance.

To sit there and just test these guys, who are subject to all sorts of placebo, stress, numerical bias and Cthulhu belief, is not enough to tell what's what.
If you were to measure a significant difference, that means there *is* a significant difference.
